html:
Desirability isn’t just about visual appeal: it’s one of the most important user factors

Kai Wong

6 min read

13 hours ago

--

“The first way designers should get involved in metrics is validating the problem with desirability.” A design manager told me, and he wasn’t alone.

I’ve been interviewing several design leaders to understand how they understand and hit metrics and business objectives, and one word keeps popping up: desirability.

Desirability is often an odd concept, as it’s not a metric. Moreover, it’s a ‘secondary concept’ that gets grouped when discussing UX.

However, many design leaders believe that designers shouldn’t just know about desirability: designers should be responsible for this metric.

Here’s why.

Are you really solving a user’s problem?

To give a basic definition, desirability is a strategic part of UX that revolves around a single user question:

  • Have you defined (and solved) the right problem for users?
